Description: Scarab carved from steatite; back lost, only the base survived; underside bearing deeply incised decoration representing a standing man, legs apart, holding to his sides a seated lion to left and a griffin to right; longitudinally pierced.
Curator's comments: The motif of this scarab (first published in Gardner 1888, pl. 18, 73) figures the 'Master of the Animals'. A similar theme, though depicted quite differently, can be found on an Egyptian blue scarab produced at the Scarab Factory (Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H5115.6): it represents a running man holding a lion upside down in each hand (Gardner 1888, pl. 18, 58; Gorton 1996, 127, type 35 no. 7) . Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.01) (phase 3)
